description: From Middle English norice, from Old French norrice, from Late Latin nūtrīcia, noun based on Latin nūtrīcius (“that which nourishes”), from nūtrīx (“wet nurse”), from nūtriō (“to suckle”).

entries.meaning: A person (usually a woman) who takes care of other people’s young.
examples: They hired a nurse to care for their young boy.

entries.meaning: A person trained to provide care for the sick.
examples: The nurse made her rounds through the hospital ward.

entries.meaning: (figurative) One who, or that which, brings up, rears, causes to grow, trains, or fosters.
examples: Eton College has been called "the chief nurse of England's statesmen".

entries.meaning: (horticulture) A shrub or tree that protects a young plant.
(nautical) A lieutenant or first officer who takes command when the captain is unfit for his place.
A larva of certain trematodes, which produces cercariae by asexual reproduction.

verbs.description: nurse (third-person singular simple present nurses, present participle nursing, simple past and past participle nursed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To breastfeed: to feed (a baby) at the breast; to suckle.
examples: She believes that nursing her baby will make him strong and healthy.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To breastfeed: to be fed at the breast.
(transitive) To care for (someone), especially in sickness; to tend to.
examples: She nursed him back to health.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To treat kindly and with extra care.
examples: She nursed the rosebush and that season it bloomed.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To manage with care and economy.
(transitive) To drink slowly, to make it last.
examples: Rob was nursing a small beer.

entries.meaning: To hold closely to one's chest
examples: Would you like to nurse the puppy?

entries.meaning: (billiards, transitive) To strike (billiard balls) gently, so as to keep them in good position during a series of shots.
examples: It is to our interest to let Lee and Johnston come together, just as a billiard-player would nurse the balls when he has them in a nice place

description: Uncertain; earlier (16th century) nusse, nuse. Perhaps from huss, through metanalysis of "an huss" as "a nuss".
